<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 is: A for loop shall be well-formed.
The three clauses of a for statement are the:
1. First clause shall be empty or an expression whose set the value of the loop counter or define and intialize the loop counter.
2. Second clause shall be an expression that has no persistent side effects, and shall use the loop counter and optionally loop control flags, and shall not use any other object that is modified in the for loop body.
3.Third clause shall be an expression whose modify only the value of the loop counter, and shall not use objects that are modified in the for loop body.
4. There shall only be one loop counter in a for loop, which shall not be modified in for loop body. A loop control flag is defined as single identifier denoting an object with Boolean type that is used in the second clause. The behaviour of a for loop body includes the behaviour of any functions called within that statement. 
</misra_rule>

<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_uio_dev_open:
```c
static int metal_uio_dev_open(struct linux_bus *lbus, struct linux_device *ldev)
{
	char *instance, path[SYSFS_PATH_MAX];
	struct linux_driver *ldrv = ldev->ldrv;
	unsigned long *phys, offset = 0, size = 0;
	struct metal_io_region *io;
	struct dlist *dlist;
	int result, i;
	void *virt;
	int irq_info;


	ldev->fd = -1;
	ldev->device.irq_info = (void *)-1;

	ldev->sdev = sysfs_open_device(lbus->bus_name, ldev->dev_name);
	if (!ldev->sdev) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "device %s:%s not found\n",
			  lbus->bus_name, ldev->dev_name);
		return -ENODEV;
	}
	metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "opened sysfs device %s:%s\n",
		  lbus->bus_name, ldev->dev_name);

	result = metal_uio_dev_bind(ldev, ldrv);
	if (result)
		return result;

	result = snprintf(path, sizeof(path), "%s/uio", ldev->sdev->path);
	if (result >= (int)sizeof(path))
		return -EOVERFLOW;
	dlist = sysfs_open_directory_list(path);
	if (!dlist) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "failed to scan class path %s\n",
			  path);
		return -errno;
	}

	dlist_for_each_data(dlist, instance, char) {
		result = snprintf(ldev->cls_path, sizeof(ldev->cls_path),
				  "%s/%s", path, instance);
		if (result >= (int)sizeof(ldev->cls_path))
			return -EOVERFLOW;
		result = snprintf(ldev->dev_path, sizeof(ldev->dev_path),
				  "/dev/%s", instance);
		if (result >= (int)sizeof(ldev->dev_path))
			return -EOVERFLOW;
		break;
	}
	sysfs_close_list(dlist);

	if (sysfs_path_is_dir(ldev->cls_path) != 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "invalid device class path %s\n",
			  ldev->cls_path);
		return -ENODEV;
	}

	i = 0;
	do {
		if (!access(ldev->dev_path, F_OK))
			break;
		usleep(10);
		i++;
	} while (i < 1000);
	if (i >= 1000) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "failed to open file %s, timeout.\n",
			  ldev->dev_path);
		return -ENODEV;
	}
	result = metal_open(ldev->dev_path, 0);
	if (result < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "failed to open device %s\n",
			  ldev->dev_path, strerror(-result));
		return result;
	}
	ldev->fd = result;

	metal_log(METAL_LOG_DEBUG, "opened %s:%s as %s\n",
		  lbus->bus_name, ldev->dev_name, ldev->dev_path);

	for (i = 0, result = 0; !result && i < METAL_MAX_DEVICE_REGIONS; i++) {
		phys = &ldev->region_phys[ldev->device.num_regions];
		result = (result ? result :
			 metal_uio_read_map_attr(ldev, i, "offset", &offset));
		result = (result ? result :
			 metal_uio_read_map_attr(ldev, i, "addr", phys));
		result = (result ? result :
			 metal_uio_read_map_attr(ldev, i, "size", &size));
		result = (result ? result :
			 metal_map(ldev->fd, i * getpagesize(), size, 0, 0, &virt));
		if (!result) {
			io = &ldev->device.regions[ldev->device.num_regions];
			metal_io_init(io, virt, phys, size, -1, 0, NULL);
			ldev->device.num_regions++;
		}
	}

	irq_info = 1;
	if (write(ldev->fd, &irq_info, sizeof(irq_info)) <= 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_INFO,
			  "%s: No IRQ for device %s.\n",
			  __func__, ldev->dev_name);
		ldev->device.irq_num =  0;
		ldev->device.irq_info = (void *)-1;
	} else {
		ldev->device.irq_num =  1;
		ldev->device.irq_info = (void *)(intptr_t)ldev->fd;
		metal_linux_irq_register_dev(&ldev->device, ldev->fd);
	}

	return 0;
}
```

result = (result ? result :
			 metal_map(ldev->fd, i * getpagesize(), size, 0, 0, &virt));
explanation: Only for-loop constructs (and loop-like macros that expand to for) are relevant to MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2. The explicit for statement above uses two assignments in the first clause (i and result) rather than initializing a single loop counter, and the loop-condition uses 'result' (a non-Boolean integer used as a control flag) while 'result' is also modified in the loop body — these are precisely the aspects that need investigation under Rule 14.2. The multiple in-loop assignments to 'result' (the four 'result = (result ? ...' lines) demonstrate that 'result' is modified within the loop body while also appearing in the second clause, so they must be examined together with the for header. The macro invocation dlist_for_each_data(...) must be checked because it may expand to a for statement; its expansion could violate the rule even if the source here is a macro call. Other code fragments in the function are not reported because they are not for loops (e.g. the do { ... } while loop, if/else blocks, function calls, assignments that are not part of a for header/condition/iteration-expression, and the later write/open logic) and so are outside the scope of Rule 14.2. No other for-loop or for-like macro occurrences are present in the provided function besides the ones listed.
